description: Police anti-narcotics agents seized on Thursday some P5 billion worth of shabu when they raided a warehouse in Marilao, Bulacan, one of the biggest drug hauls in the government's campaign against illegal drugs. Archie Francisco Gamboa, chief of the Philippine National Police, said the operation also resulted in the arrest of Chinese national Yuwen Cai and...
text:
By Aaron Recuenco

Police anti-narcotics agents seized on Thursday (June 4) some P5 billion worth
of shabu (crystal methamphetamine) when they raided a warehouse in Marilao,
Bulacan, one of the biggest drug hauls in the government's campaign against
illegal drugs.

Gen. Archie Francisco Gamboa, chief of the Philippine National Police (PNP),
said the operation also resulted in the arrest of Chinese national Yuwen Cai
and Filipinas Angela Tulio and Ma. Lyn Tulio.

The Chinese suspect, according to Gamboa, appears to be the trusted man of the
drug syndicate while the two Filipinas could be associates tasked to do
errands for the arrested foreigner.

Gamboa said the operation was an offshoot of a surveillance operation which
the PNP Drug Enforcement Group has been conducting against a drug syndicate
operating in the country.

"There was a necessity to conduct surveillance hoping that we may find
something here, and it turned out positive," Gamboa said in an interview.

He was referring to the warehouse at #2 Reley St., in Barangay Lias, Marilao
City. The operation was conducted at around 3 p.m.

Seized were 63 boxes containing approximately 756 kilograms of shabu.

"With the packaging, we believe that these are importation because we believe,
and even PDEA (Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency) believes that there are no
longer big laboratories in the country," Gamboa said.

"What we have here are kitchen-type [laboratories] which can produce
approximately five to seven kilos of shabu every week. With more than 700
kilos, imagine how many weeks they can do that," he added.

Gamboa said the packaging itself does not suggest that the substance was made
in a kitchen-type laboratory. He said the packaging contains Japanese
characters, which he said, could be a deviation from the actual origin of the
illegal drugs.

Given the huge quantity of the illegal drugs, Gamboa said the shabu may also
have been meant for distribution in the Visayas and Mindanao.

Based on the estimate, the drug haul has a street value of P5.14 billion.

CAPTION(S):

(Photo via Aaron Recuenco/MANILA BULLETIN)

title: P5B worth of illegal drugs seized from Bulacan warehouse.(Luzon)
html:
By Aaron Recuenco

Police anti-narcotics agents seized on Thursday (June 4) some P5 billion worth of shabu (crystal methamphetamine) when they raided a warehouse in Marilao, Bulacan, one of the biggest drug hauls in the government's campaign against illegal drugs.

Gen. Archie Francisco Gamboa, chief of the Philippine National Police (PNP), said the operation also resulted in the arrest of Chinese national Yuwen Cai and Filipinas Angela Tulio and Ma. Lyn Tulio.

The Chinese suspect, according to Gamboa, appears to be the trusted man of the drug syndicate while the two Filipinas could be associates tasked to do errands for the arrested foreigner.

Gamboa said the operation was an offshoot of a surveillance operation which the PNP Drug Enforcement Group has been conducting against a drug syndicate operating in the country.

"There was a necessity to conduct surveillance hoping that we may find something here, and it turned out positive," Gamboa said in an interview.

He was referring to the warehouse at #2 Reley St., in Barangay Lias, Marilao City. The operation was conducted at around 3 p.m.

Seized were 63 boxes containing approximately 756 kilograms of shabu.

"With the packaging, we believe that these are importation because we believe, and even PDEA (Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency) believes that there are no longer big laboratories in the country," Gamboa said.

"What we have here are kitchen-type [laboratories] which can produce approximately five to seven kilos of shabu every week. With more than 700 kilos, imagine how many weeks they can do that," he added.

Gamboa said the packaging itself does not suggest that the substance was made in a kitchen-type laboratory. He said the packaging contains Japanese characters, which he said, could be a deviation from the actual origin of the illegal drugs.

Given the huge quantity of the illegal drugs, Gamboa said the shabu may also have been meant for distribution in the Visayas and Mindanao.

Based on the estimate, the drug haul has a street value of P5.14 billion.

CAPTION(S):

(Photo via Aaron Recuenco/MANILA BULLETIN)
